topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Vikrama Dhiman, his role leading product at Gojek, and frames the episode around PM skill-building, career growth, and transitioning into product management.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Uizard and Webflow.

topics.title: Why Vikrama is known for talent building
topics.summary: Lenny sets context on Vikrama’s reputation for developing PM and design talent and helping people transition into PM; Vikrama agrees to dive into these topics.

topics.title: Traits of fast-growing PMs and the 3Ws
topics.summary: Vikrama explains why “cool products” don’t guarantee growth and introduces his career growth framework: what you produce, what you bring to the table, and what your operating model is.

topics.title: What you produce: outputs to outcomes progression
topics.summary: They discuss focusing on tangible outputs early (shipping, experiments, GTM contributions), then moving toward outcomes and leadership—without ever abandoning strong execution.

topics.title: Does product area impact matter for growth?
topics.summary: Vikrama shares a personal example showing that craft and execution quality can outweigh working on the most visible product area; Lenny reinforces execution as the early-career differentiator.

topics.title: Concrete examples of strong outputs: be useful
topics.summary: Vikrama gives practical ways to generate outputs (draft briefs, slides, first drafts, unblock leaders) and warns against over-indexing on “mini-CEO” strategy work too early.

topics.title: What you bring: artifacts and impact-on-impact
topics.summary: Vikrama argues career growth requires demonstrating contribution via high-quality PM artifacts (PRDs, strategy docs, notes, experiment plans, Jira hygiene) across data, design, tech, and strategy.

topics.title: Operating model: stakeholder collaboration and decision-making
topics.summary: Vikrama outlines three tenets for working well cross-functionally: raise hard issues without being hard to work with, elevate topics without self-importance, and drive decisions without owning all decisions.

topics.title: How to push back effectively without friction
topics.summary: They discuss pushback as a key PM skill; Vikrama recommends de-escalating emotional discussions into logical, equal-footing conversations to maintain trust and momentum.

topics.title: Why careers stall: control, change, and self-stories
topics.summary: Vikrama explains three common growth blockers: focusing on what’s outside your control, slowing your rate of change, and limiting self-narratives (e.g., “high agency” as an excuse).

topics.title: Vikrama’s recalibration at Gojek and mindful agency
topics.summary: He shares how working with stronger peers reset his self-assessment, reinforced a “learner” identity, and led him to evolve from “high agency” to “mindful agency,” especially across cultures.

topics.title: Using feedback without overwhelm: pick leverage areas
topics.summary: Vikrama advises channeling feedback into specific skill axes and improving one high-leverage area at a time; he suggests pairing strengths/weaknesses across data, tech, design/research, then strategy.

topics.title: Transitioning into PM: tailoring growth plans by background
topics.summary: He describes how Gojek transitions people from growth or research into PM by assigning work that stretches missing skills (design vs tech/data), with examples like driver redesign and risk/enterprise work.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Coda and how Lenny uses it for podcast planning and product team planning workflows.

topics.title: What is a PM: ambiguity, art vs science, glue role
topics.summary: They discuss why PM is hard to define, how stakeholders get confused, and a practical heuristic: if it blocks product progress, the PM should help; Vikrama frames PM as the connector across strategy, tech, design, and data.
